summary: Statue of a running Nike, dedicated by Kallimachos
subject_description: See <rs type="sculpture">Athens, Acropolis 690</rs>.
title: Nike of Kallimachos

name: Athens, EM 6339
summary: Inscribed base of Kallimachos
inscription:
The inscribed column has been restored by Harrison as follows:[*K*A*L*L*I*M*A*X*O*S *M'*A*N]*E*Q*E*K*E*N *A*F*I*D*N*A*I*O[*S] *T*A*Q*E*N*A*I*A*I*A*N[*G*E*L*O*N *A*Q]*A*N*A*T*O*N *H*O*I *O[*L*U*M*P*O*I *H*E*D*R*A*S *E*P]*E*X*O*I*S*I*N[*N*I*K*E*S*A*S *P*O*L*E]*M*A*R*X*O[*S] *A*Q*E*N*A*I*O*N *T*O*N *A*G*O*N*A*T*O*N *M*A[*L *A*R*I*S*T*E*U*O*N *H]*E*L*E*N *O*N*O*M[*A *M*E*N *K*A*L*L*I*S*T*O*N*P*A*I*S*I*N *A*Q*E*N*A*I*O*N *M*N[*E*M*E*A *D*E* *H*E*S *A*R*E*T*E*S] or *M*N[*E*M*E*N *D'*A*R*E*T*E*S *K*A*T*E*L*E*I*P*E*N]

Harrison's translation is as follows: "Kallimachos of Aphidna dedicated me to Athena--I am the messenger of the immortals who have their thrones on Olympos--because he was victorious, when he was Polemarch, in the festival fo the Athenians. And fighting most bravely of them all he won fairest renown for Athenian men-at-arms and a memorial of his own valour."
title: Base of Nike of Kallimachos

name: Potter Relief
summary: A seated man holding a kylix
other_bibliography: <bibl>Berger 1970, 98-99, fig. 119, 183 n. 254</bibl>; <bibl>Karouzos 1961, 52 E 16, 53</bibl>; <bibl>Lippold 1950, 85</bibl>; <bibl>Raubitschek 1949, 75 no. 70</bibl>; <bibl>Beazley 1946</bibl>; <bibl>Payne 1936, 48, pls. 129-30</bibl>; Schuchhardt in <bibl>Langlotz & Schuchhardt 1943, 301 no. 422, pl. 176</bibl>; <bibl>Dickins 1912, 272</bibl>
dimensions: Restored: H. 0.122 m; W. 0.76 m; Th. 0.17 m; H. of plinth 0.07 m; W. of projections on the sides 0.021 m each.
condition_description: Restored from many fragments.
form_style_description: The relief was framed by two thin projections (bearing the inscription) on the right and left edges, a plinth below, and crowned with a curved finial surmounted by a bronze central akroterion, one cutting for which is preserved on the right side.
subject_description:
A bearded potter, seated profile to the left on a stool, holds a kylix (cup), just below waist level, in his left hand, while another dangles from his finger. He wears a hiamation, draped diagonally across his left shoulder. His right hand, which is missing, must have been extended in front of his body.

The identity of the potter is mentioned by the damaged inscription, which has been restored as Euphronios or (more likely) Pamphaios.
title: Potter Relief

name: Athens, Agora I 4571
findspot: Athens, Acropolis (found on the North slope in 1937)
inscription:
The frame is inscribed, and has been restored by Raubitschek as follows:...]*A*I*O*S *A*N*E*Q*E*K*E*N [*T*A*Q*E*N*A*I*A*I] *D*E*K*A*T*E*N*E*N[*D*O*I*O*S *E*P*O*I*E*S]*E*N.

This may be roughly translated as "...aios dedicated this as a tithe to Athena. Endoios made it."
title: Inscribed fragment of the Potter Relief

name: Athens, EM 6520
inscription: See <rs type="sculpture">Athens, Agora I 4571</rs>
title: Inscribed fragment of the Potter Relief

name: Athens, Acropolis 720
summary: Head of a balding centaur with his mouth half opened
other_notes: Foreshortening is apparent in the right side of this centaur, which would have been closest to the back wall and thus nearly impossible to see from ground level.
title: Centaur head

name: Athens, Acropolis 885
summary: Nude torso of Poseidon from the Parthenon, West Pediment
condition_description: Broken off just above the waist, and below each shoulder; the head and neck are also missing.
subject_description: Poseidon's muscular, naked torso twists slightly to his left, while he raises his right shoulder, presumably in striking his trident at the rock from which his salt spring emerges.
title: Torso of Poseidon

name: Athens, Acropolis 887
summary: Naked torso and thighs of a river god (?), leaning to the right
form_style_description: This figure is commonly thought not to have received the "finishing touches."
title: Torso of Ilissos

name: Athens, Acropolis 881
summary: Torso of a goddess, wearing a sleeveless, belted chiton, with straps crossing her chest diagonally
condition_description: Broken roughly on all sides, missing thighs and below, arms and shoulders, most of the neck and head.
other_notes: A head, <rs type="sculpture">Athens, Acropolis 935</rs>, is thought to belong to this figure.
title: Torso of Selene

name: Athens, Acropolis 888
summary: Legs of a woman seated on a rock, wearing a himation over a chiton with a double overfold
condition_description: This fragment constitutes the back of a female figure seated on a rock.
other_notes: While E. Berger has furthered L. Ross' suggestion that this fragment comes from <rs type="sculpture">Parthenon EP.U</rs>, other suggestions have been that it belongs to <rs type="sculpture">Parthenon EP.D</rs> or <rs type="sculpture">Parthenon EP.T</rs>.
title: Seated woman, from the <rs type="sculpture">Parthenon, East Pediment</rs>

name: Athens, Acropolis 1363
summary: Legs of a woman seated (on a rock?), wearing a himation over a chiton
condition_description: This piece constitutes the legs of a woman, missing the front of her feet and most of her left foreleg.
title: Legs of a seated woman, perhaps one of the daughters of Erechtheus

name: Athens, Acropolis 1362
summary: Athena wearing an aegis over a belted peplos with a long overfold
other_bibliography: W.-H. Schuchhardt in <hi rend="ital">AJA</hi> 77 (1973) 240; W.B. Dinsmoor, "The Repair of the Athena Parthenos," <hi rend="ital">AJA</hi> 38 (1934) 103; <bibl>Casson 1922, 260</bibl>
findspot: Athens, Acropolis (found in 1860 near the Propylaia)
condition_description: Missing the head, arms, lower left leg, feet, and base; many ends of drapery are chipped off.
title: Small copy of Athena Parthenos

name: Athens, Acropolis 705
summary: A centaur seizing a Lapith woman
findspot: Athens, Acropolis (found in Spring 1833 outside the SW corner of the Parthenon)
condition_description: Missing the heads of both figures, the left arm, tail, and left leg of the centaur, the right hand, right arm, and some drapery of the Lapith woman, as well as most of the background.
other_notes: The resemblance of the Lapith woman's drapery to that of Procne in <rs type="sculpture">Athens, Acropolis 1358</rs>, has encouraged scholars to attribute this particular metope to Alkamenes, who is known to have sculpted that statue.
title: Parthenon SM.12

name: Athens, Acropolis 882 etc.
title: Fragments of horses from the West Pediment of the Parthenon

name: Athens, Acropolis 6510
condition_description: Comprised of rejoined fragments
other_notes: These fragments, along with some olive tree fragments in the storerooms, were formerly thought to have belonged to the olive tree of Athena in the center of the West Pediment of Athena.
technique_description: Deep drilling indicates a Hadrianic or later date for this work.
title: Snake entwined around a tree trunk

name: Athens, Acropolis 1163
summary: The feet and lower legs of a man, wearing a himation, walking to the left
title: Part of figure 8 from Parthenon, NF.3

name: Athens, Acropolis 1100
summary: Hind legs of two horses, advancing to the left
condition_description: A single triangular fragment preserves the lower right corner of NF.13.
title: Fragment of Parthenon, NF.13

name: Athens, Acropolis 3369
summary: Head and upper body of an apobates, facing left, wearing a cuirass and helmet, jumping onto a chariot
title: Head and upper body of figure 47 from Parthenon NF.12

name: Athens, Acropolis 1122
summary: Head of a youth, wearing a petasos, facing to the right
condition_description: Much of the surface is chipped away, although the face (minus the nose) is well preserved).
title: Youth from the South Frieze of the Parthenon

name: Athens, Acropolis 855
summary: Head of Iris (?)
findspot: Athens, built into the Byzantine wall SW of the Acropolis (found in 1889).
condition_description: Broken roughly diagonally, so that this fragments preserves part of the upper edge and part of the left edge of slab 5; the surface is in excellent condition, only slightly chipped.
subject_description: The head, normally thought to belong to Iris (also interpreted as Hebe), faces profile to the left, as if the goddess turns to look back over her right shoulder at the gods seated to her left (and the procession reaching them). Her hair is tied in a pony tail. Part of a large wing fills the background space to the left of her face.
title: Figure from slab 5 of the Parthenon, East Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1189
summary: Head of a girl, probably an Arrhephoros
condition_description: Broken off at the middle of the neck and all around the head, missing the tip of the nose, and the top of the head.
subject_description: This fragment represents the head of a girl, probably an arrhephoros, with several bands wrapped around her head, somewhat binding her thick, wavy hair. She is shown profile to the left.
title: Head of figure 60 from Slab 8 of the Parthenon, East Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1116
summary: Hind legs of a cow
condition_description: Roughly broken on all sides except the right edge, and eroded in patches on the surface.
title: Fragment from slab 3 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1156
summary: Fragments of a chariot wheel and two horses (forelegs)
condition_description: Preserves the corner of a slab, with the finished right and bottom edges.
title: Fragment from lower right corner of slab 24 of the Parthenon, South Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1149
summary: Hand of a rider and part of the head of a horse
condition_description: This fragment is almost rectangular but preserves no finished edges.
title: Part of figure 74 of slab 24 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1166
summary: Torso of a male figure wearing a himation
condition_description: Broken roughly on all sides, with a weathered surface.
title: A fragment of the Parthenon, North Frieze (perhaps from slab 4)

name: Athens, Acropolis 1230
summary: Part of the neck of a horse and the head of another
condition_description: Broken roughly on all sides, with a weathered surface.
title: A fragment of the Parthenon, North Frieze (perhaps from slab 22)

name: Athens, Acropolis 1127+1134
summary: Head and neck of a horse and head and upper body of a man
condition_description: Two joining fragments, preserving part of the upper edge of slab 21; otherwise broken all around.
title: Part of figure 52 of slab 21 of the Parthenon, South Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 864
summary: Four hydriaphoroi, or water carriers and a double-flute player
findspot: Athens, Acropolis, found in the colonnade of the Parthenon (in 1833)
condition_description: One large fragment and at least one small fragment (preserving the upper right corner) comprise this slab, which is heavily chipped on all sides and on the drapery, with several diagonal solution cracks; it is otherwise well preserved.
subject_description: Three youths, dressed in himatia, advance in 3/4-view to the left and carry water jars (hydriae) on their left shoulders, holding the handles with their upraised right hands. A fourth youth crouches to raise his hydria off the ground. A musician, playing the double flutes, is shown on the far right, although only his/her hands and some drapery appear.
title: Part of slab 6 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1062
summary: Left leg of a rider on a horse
condition_description: Roughly broken on all sides, with a surface flaking off.
title: Fragment of figure 85 of slab 27 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1167
summary: Part of the torso of a man facing to the right
condition_description: Comprised of two rejoined fragments, splintered at the left end of the break, with an eroded surface, especially on the man's arm.
title: Fragment from the Parthenon, South Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 867
summary: Cavalry
condition_description: Broken roughly on all sides, and cracked/scratched on the surface.
title: Parthenon SF.16

name: Athens, Acropolis 857
summary: Three youths driving cattle to sacrifice, and the hands of a fourth youth
findspot: Athens, Acropolis, near the East end of the North side of the Parthenon, probably just below its original position.
condition_description: Most of a large slab, preserving the left edge and most of the top and bottom edges, but broken roughtly on the right; some solution cracks and pitted areas mar the surface; the faces of the second and third figures have been broken off.
subject_description: Two cows, led by three draped youths, the third of whom is shown with his garment slipping off his arms. The hands of a fourth youth are shown at the far right. The head of the second cow is shown, thrown up in the air, with corresponding raised forelegs, to indicate her resistance.
title: Part of slab 2 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 3319
summary: Head of a Lapith, perhaps from the Parthenon, South Metope 2
collection_history: Broken off between 1674 and 1765.
condition_description: Broken off at the top of the neck, all around the head, and missing most of the nose.
title: Head of a Lapith, facing left

name: Athens, Acropolis 860
summary: Four youths leading ewes to sacrifice
condition_description: Most of the bottom edge and some of the top edge is preserved, whereas the slab is roughly broken off on both sides. Horizontal solution cracks and severe chipping on all figures, particularly the second youth, have erased much of the detail on the surface; only the feet of the first youth, for example, are now visible.
subject_description: Four youths, each wearing a himation, lead at least three ewes to sacrifice. The third youth, advancing profile to the left, lays his hand on the back of a sheep, while the second turns to look at him, with his body in 3/4-view to the left and his head 3/4-view to the right. The fourth youth turns 3/4-view to the right, presumably to view to the advancing procession.
title: Part of slab 4 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 856
summary: Poseidon, Apollo, Artemis, and Aphrodite
condition_description: Comprised of several joining fragments and other non-joining fragments that preserve the left and of the slab.
title: Left end of slab 6 of the Parthenon, East Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 877
summary: Three ergastinai, or peplos weavers, advancing to the right
condition_description: Several rejoined fragments, with restorations in plaster, comprise most of the center part of this slab; missing all heads and feet.
title: Fragments of slab 2 of the Parthenon, East Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 797
summary: A marshall, standing frontally, beckoning the procession
condition_description: Several non-joining fragments comprise the right hand and most of the body of one marshall and the drapery of an adjacent figure.
title: Fragment of slab 1 of the Parthenon, East Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 873
summary: Thallophoroi
condition_description: Broken on all sides, this fragment preserves most of the center of the frieze block; surface details, such as hands, are worn off.
subject_description: At least five men, probably thallophoroi, or branch bearers in the Panathenaic procession, wear himatia, and advance to the right.
title: Parthenon SF.36

name: Athens, Acropolis 1110
summary: Head and shoulder of a rider and adjacent horse head
condition_description: This roughly triangular fragment preserves the left edge of slab 37, but is otherwise broken all around; the surface is heavily eroded.
title: Part of a rider 113 from slab 37 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1140
summary: Upper body of skaphephoros
condition_description: Roughly broken, and missing large portions of the surface (of the face and upper chest).
subject_description: This man, probably a skaphephoros, or bearer of a tray of offerings, wears a himation, holds his tray over his left shoulder, and advances to the right.
title: Part of figure 106 from the Parthenon, South Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 869
summary: Cavalry
condition_description: Comprised of several rejoined fragments, with weathered surfaces, comprising the lower right half of this frieze block.
title: Parthenon SF.18

name: Athens, Acropolis 1145
summary: Head of a rider and the following horse
condition_description: A roughly triangular fragment preserving part of the upper edge of slab 13.
title: Part of figure 130 from slab 13 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 868
summary: Cavalry
condition_description: Comprised of several rejoined fragments, on most of which the surface is well preserved.
title: Parthenon SF.17

name: Athens, Acropolis 866
summary: Cavalry
condition_description: Comprised of two or more rejoined fragments; much of the surface has flaked off.
title: Parthenon SF.14

name: Athens, Acropolis 1066
summary: Part of the feet on an Eponymous hero leaning on a staff
condition_description: This fragment preserves part of the right edge of slab 3 and some of the plinth; otherwise broken roughly.
title: Part of figure 19 from slab 3 of the Parthenon, East Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1309
summary: Head of a Lapith woman, turned slightly to the left
condition_description: Broken off at the middle of the neck, and all around the head.
title: Fragment of the Parthenon, South Metope, perhaps from metope 2

name: Athens, Acropolis 6511
summary: Lapith head
collection_history: The head was identified by F. Studniczka in 1920, while in storage at the Athens, National Museum; after WWII it was returned to the Acropolis.
condition_description: Broken off at  the middle of the neck; the face bears a gouge on the left cheek and most of the nose is broken off.
title: Head from the Parthenon, South Metope 6

name: Athens, Acropolis 875
summary: Musicians playing the kithara
condition_description: Comprised of at least seven rejoined fragments, preserving some of the top and bottom edges but none of the side edges. The surface is worn, with cracks, chips, and adhesions.
subject_description: Several musicians (at least three), standing in a variety of poses, advance in the procession to the left, and play the kithara; another musician (now lost) was originally shown on the left, as indicated in a drawing by Jacques Carrey.
title: Most of slab 8 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 865
summary: One thallophoros and seven bearded men, perhaps Attic heroes
findspot: Athens, Acropolis (found in 1865 at the Southwest corner of the Parthenon)
condition_description: Comprised of one large piece and another separate fragment that fills much of the lower left corner. Much of the right and bottom edges are preserfed, along with some of the top and left edges; Both top corners are missing. The surface is eroded, and facial details have worn away.
subject_description: A thallophoros, or olive branch bearer, draped in a himation, at the left of this slab, clearly belongs with the group on slab 9 (<rs type="sculpture">Athens, Acropolis 865</rs>). Following him is a group of seven bearded men, perhaps Attic heroes, standing in a variety of poses; the first turns slightly to the right to face the others, while he raises both hands to his head, probably to crown himself with a wreath.
title: Slab 10 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 876
summary: Thallophoroi, or men carrying olive branches
condition_description: Comprised of four or more rejoined fragments, with some restorations in the gaps, preserving some of the bottom and right edges, but broken on the other sides, and the bodies of three of a group of men. The surface is weathered, with cracks and eroded patches.
subject_description: At least three men, standing close together, in near profile to the left, advance in the procession. Each wears a himation and carries an olive branch (missing, as the painted detail has now deteriorated) in his right hand.
title: Slab 9 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 874
summary: Apobates contest
condition_description: Two rejoined fragments preserve part of the left edge of this slab, which is roughly broken on all other sides. Some of the surface has dissolved, but it is otherwise in good condition.
subject_description: A pair of galloping horses approaches a youth, facing nearly frontal, but slightly to the right, with his legs astride. He wears only a himation draped loosely over his shoulders.
title: Slab 11 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 871
summary: A four horse chariot in the apobates contest passes in front of a marshall
condition_description: This slab lacks only the top and the lower left corner. The surface is marred with adhesions, stains, solution cracks, and other losses.
title: Slab 17 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 859
summary: Apobates contest
condition_description: Comprised of a single slab, broken roughly on the top and right side and chipped on the other edges. Some of the heads have eroded.
subject_description: An apobates athlete, armed and wearing a short exomis, leaps onto a chariot, and is shown 3/4-view to the left. The charioteer, standing profile to the left, behind the apobates, holds the reins of the chariot. A youth, striding to the left, but turning his head to the right, serves as marshall for the procession. He wears a himation over his shoulders, but his his nude front is revealed. The head and forelegs of a horse--at the front of the procession--appear at the far right of the slab.
title: Slab 19 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 872
summary: Apobates contest
condition_description: Comprised of several rejoined fragments, preserving most of the center of the relief and the lower right corner. The only other edges that are preserved are parts of the left edge and the top (left) edge. The upper part is in the British Museum.
subject_description: An armed apobates contestant, wearing a cuirass over his chitoniskos, runs profile to the left, and is flanked by a charioteer, also shown profile to the left. Behind them stands a groom, 3/4-view to the right, wearing a chlamys, who attends to two (or more) horses, probably a chariot group that is about to begin the contest.
title: Slab 22 of the Parthenon, North Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1077
summary: Standing female figure
condition_description: Comprised of two or more joining fragments; the figure lacks her head, neck, right torso including arm, left arm, and feet, as well as some of the billowing drapery.
form_style_description: Brouskari reports that Hill placed this figure in the first position of block 1 of the South Frieze or the first position of block 3 of the East Frieze.
subject_description: Female figure, standing with her weight on her right leg, and her left leg raised slightly. She wears a himation over a high belted chiton, a pose that, according to Brouskari recalls Pheidias' Aphrodite Ourania.
title: Standing female from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 2830
summary: Female figure, seated to the right, wearing a chiton and a himation
condition_description: Comprised of two large joining fragments, this figure lacks head, forearms, derrire, ankles and feet, as well as some of the surface of the drapery and chair. The surface is severely eroded.
form_style_description: Brouskari notes that Pallat suggested that this figure blonged to the first position on block 7 of the North side of the North Porch.
title: Seated female figure from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1078
summary: Female figure, clad in chiton and himation, seated in 3/4-view to the left on a rock, with her upper body turned to the front.
condition_description: The drapery and other surfaces of this figure are in good condition. This figure, comprised of one large fragment, lacks head, neck, right torso including right arm, left forearm, and feet.
form_style_description: Brouskari reports that Hill placed this figure in the first position on block 5 of the East Frieze.
title: Seated female figure from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1076
summary: Enthroned female figure, seated 3/4-view to the left, wearing a chiton and a himation.
condition_description: Comprised of three (or more) large joining fragments, this figure lacks head, neck, both shoulders, forearms, right knee, both feet and ankles, and much of her chair. The surface is severly weathered, particularly on the left side.
form_style_description: Brouskari reports that Hill placed this figure on the third or fourth position on block 6 of the East Frieze (but Fowler in <bibl>Caskey et al. 1927</bibl> argued against it).
title: Enthroned female figure from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1072
summary: Female figure, wearing a belted chiton and himation, seated 3/4-view to the left on a rock
condition_description: This severely weathered figure, comprised of one large fragment, lacks head and neck, left shoulder and arm, right forearm, feet and ankles.
form_style_description: Brouskari reports that Pallat placed this figure on position 3 of block 6 (2) of the North side of the North Porch.
title: Seated female figure from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1073
summary: A standing man behind a kneeling youth
condition_description: Comprised of three (or more) rejoined fragments. The surfaces are in relatively good condition. The standing figure lacks head and neck, left shoulder, and both forearms. The kneeling figure lacks his right arm (below the shoulder) and his right leg (below the thigh). Much of the plinth on which they were supported remains.
form_style_description: Brouskari notes that Hill assigned this group to the fourth position in block 1 of the South Frieze.
subject_description: A standing man leaning on a staff (?) and a youth kneeling at his feet are both dressed in himatia. According to Brouskari scholars dispute the action of the kneeling boy. Milchfer and Schne thought that he was shown in the process of tying his sandals, while Robert suggested that he was writing the oracle (an interpretation that Casson preferred).
title: Group of two male figures from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1074
summary: A female figure, wearing a billowing chiton, alights on the ground
condition_description: This figure, heavily chipped and weathered, is comprised of one fragment that preserves only her lower torso and legs.
form_style_description: Brouskari reports that Pallat placed this figure on first position of block 4 of the East side of the North Porch.
title: Advancing female figure (Nike?) from the Erechtheion

name: Athens, Acropolis 2829
summary: A female figure stands next to a chair draped with fabric, on which a baby (or pillow) is placed.
other_bibliography: <bibl>Boulter 1970, no. 56, pls. 21 and 23b</bibl>; <bibl>Caskey et al. 1927, 257 no. 56</bibl>
condition_description: This figure, comprised of two large joining fragments, preserves the lower torso and legs of the woman and the top of the chair (bed?) to which she attends. Her knee has chipped off, yet the drapery is relatively well preserved.
form_style_description: Brouskari reports that Pallat placed this figure on the second position of block 10 of the North side of the North Porch.
title: Standing female figure next to a chair, from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1238
summary: Female figure, wearing a chiton belted over an overfold and a himation, seated on a rock to the right.
condition_description: This single piece preseres the lower torso and legs (lacking ankles and feet, and some drapery) of a seated figure. The surface is somewhat chipped.
form_style_description: Brouskari reports that Pallat assigned this figure to the third position of block 5 (1) of the North side of the North Porch.
title: Seated female figure from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1239
summary: Figure of indeterminate gender wearing a chiton and himation, probably rising from a chair
other_bibliography: <bibl>Boulter 1970, 13 no. 18, pls. 15-16a</bibl>; <bibl>Caskey et al. 1927, 250 ff. no. 18</bibl>
condition_description: This single large, and relatively well preserved fragment, comprises the lower torso and legs (missing ends of feet), with associated drapery of the rising figure, and most of her chair (throne?).
form_style_description: Brouskari reports that Pallat placed this figure in the first position on block 10 (5) of the North side of the North Porch.
subject_description: This figure seems to be in the act of rising from a chair arm finials each comprised of a lion's-head surmounted by a sphinx. Schne has identified this figure as Athena, while Pallat has suggested Zeus.
title: Figure rising from a chair, from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1075
summary: Mother (or nurse?) and son, perhaps Athena and Erichthonios, Demeter and Iakchos, Pandrosos and Erichthonios
findspot: Athens, Acropolis (in front of the Erechtheion North Porch)
condition_description: This single large piece preserves the boy's torso, righty arm, left upper arm, and legs (except right knee, ankles, and feet), the chest, lower torso, and legs of the female figure, and the block on which she is seated. The drapery is relatively well preserved.
form_style_description: According to Brouskari, Pallat identified this group as figure 4 of block 1 on the South Frieze.
subject_description: A seated woman, wearing a himation over a belted chiton, with a boy in her lap, who reaches his right hand to his mother.
title: Mother and son group from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1293
summary: Seated figure wearing a himation--perhaps Apollo, Ge or Themis--with an omphalos held in his/her left hand
other_bibliography: <bibl>Boulter 1970, 18 no. 83, pl. 30, figs. 17-18</bibl>; <bibl>Caskey et al. 1927, 263 no. 83</bibl>
condition_description: This single piece preserves the legs and associated drapery, as well as omphalos, of a single figure; the surface is in good condition.
title: Lower part of a seated figure from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 2825
summary: Female figure--perhaps Nike--with bared left shoulder and breast and windblown drapery, running (flying?) to the left
condition_description: This single piece preserves the torso, right arm, and thighs of the figure; the remaining drapery is in good condition.
title: Running (or flying?) female figure from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1071
summary: Two female figures, probably Demeter and Kore
condition_description: A large piece preserves the torso and legs of the (right-most) chiton-clad figure, and the left torso and leg of the peplos-clad figure. A smaller joining fragment comrprises the right thigh of the latter figure. The remainign drapery is in good condition.
subject_description: Two female figures moving to the right. One wears a peplos belted over an overfold, while the other wears a himation over a thin chiton; on account of their proximity as well as their various clothing they may be identified as Demeter and Kore.
title: Group of two female figures from the Erechtheion Frieze

name: Samos I 76
summary: Upper right arm of a female figure
condition_description: This single fragment is broken roughly at top and bottom, but preserves the full width of the upper arm, just above the elbow. It is slightly scratched and stained.
subject_description: This fragment of the upper right arm of a kore (just above the elbow) retains a grooved delineation of the edge of a cape that would have cascaded over the kore's shoulders.
title: Fragment of arm of a kore

name: Athens, Acropolis 7098
summary: A calm Nike, wearing a twice belted chiton, and another Nike restraining a bull, bracing her foot against a rock
other_bibliography: G. Welter, "Vom Nikepyrgos," <hi rend="ital">ArchAnz</hi> 1939, col. 15-16, figs. 10-11; <bibl>Carpenter 1929, 67 no. 16, pl. 30</bibl>; <bibl>Casson 1921, 133 no. 3</bibl>
condition_description: Several joining fragments (and one non-joining fragment) comrpise most of the bottom and left edge of this slab. The upper portions of the bull and right-most Nike are missing, as are the face and forearms of the left-most Nike. Much of the surface has chipped off.
form_style_description: Carpenter, who attributed tis relief to Master F, assigned it to position 43 on the South side of the Parapet.
title: Two Nikai and a bull from the  Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 991
summary: Athena resting on a rock
condition_description: Several joining fragments (with some restoration) comprise the legs and lower torso of Athena, as well as her right hand and the shield on which it rests. The surface is somewhat pitted on her lap.
form_style_description: Carpenter has attributed this slab to Master D, and assigned it to position 28 on the West side of the Parapet.
subject_description: Athena rests on a rock, profile to the right, and uses another rock as her footstool. She holds her helmet on her lap, with her shield at her side, and rests her weight on her right hand as she turns to look behind her. She wears a thin chiton, and her legs are covered with a himation.
title: Athena from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1013
summary: Nike, perhaps bringing a gift to Athena?
findspot: Athens, Areopagos (the lower fragment was found on the Northeast slope of the Areopagos [Agora S 1759] and joined to the upper fragment by Harrison).
condition_description: Two joining fragments comprise the torso, both arms, and thighs of Nike. The surface is slightly scratched, with some adhesions.
form_style_description:
Nike's pose recalls the Leaning Aphrodite Type.

This figure may have come from position 26 or 28 on the South side of the Parapet.
subject_description: Nike, standing in 3/4-view to the left, wears a chiton with shoulder straps, and rests her left hand on her hip. This Nike may have stood in front of the Athena represented by <rs type="sculpture">Athens, Acropolis 991</rs>. She offers an object, perhaps the helmet represented by <rs type="sculpture">Athens, Acropolis 1001</rs>, to the goddess.
title: Nike from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1001
summary: Hand (of Nike?) holding a helmet
condition_description: A single triangular piece, which has been attached to <rs type="sculpture">Athens, Acropolis 1013</rs>), comporises the right hand of a female figure holding a helmet.
other_notes: This hand may have belonged to the Nike represented in <rs type="sculpture">Athens, Acropolis 1013</rs>.
title: Hand from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 999
summary: Nike, wearing a double-belted chiton, with her outspread wings facing frontal, perhaps adjacent to a trophy, holding an object
findspot: Athens, Acropolis, at the foot of the Nike bastion (by Yorke in 1893); a join of the right breast was discovered by G. Dontas in the museum storeroom in 1959.
condition_description: Several rejoined pieces comprise the neck, torso, upper arms, and portion of the left wing of a Nike. The surface is severaly chipped on the neck, right shoulder, right elbow and lower arm bent across the midriff.
form_style_description: Carpenter, who attributed this figure to Master C (judged to be a sculptor of lesser accomplishment), suggested that this figure was no. 25 from the West side.
title: Nike from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1003
summary: Nike standing in an upright pose, with her left leg bent, perhaps next to a trophy; she wears a sleeveless, belted chiton.
findspot: Athens, Acropolis, on the North side of the Parthenon (in 1867)
condition_description: A single pieces preserves the torso and left shoulder of a Nike; the surface of the drapery is chipped.
form_style_description: Carpenter, who attributed this figure to Master D, assigned it to position 33 on the West side of the Parapet.
title: Nike from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1004
summary: Nike, wearing belted chiton and a shield on her left arm, moves toward a trophy
findspot: Athens, Acropolis (one fragment found at the Southwest end of the Acropolis in 1893, others joined in 1876 and 1880).
condition_description: Two (or more?) joining fragments comprise the left torso, thigh, and arm of a Nike, and some of her attached shield.
form_style_description: Carpenter attributed this work to Master C, and assigned it to positions 21 or 25 on the West side of the Parapet.
title: Nike from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 972 and 2860
summary: Two Nikai leading a bull to sacrifice
condition_description: Many rejoined fragments comprise most of a single slab, missing the upper left corner and some sections in the middle. The Nikai lack both heads and right arms, as well as most of the left forearms. The head and forelegs of the bull are also missing. The knees of the left Nike are chipped severely and the background surface is stained. The drapery, where preserved, however, is in good condition.
other_notes: A copy of this relief may be found in the Uffizi Gallery in Florence.
form_style_description: Carpenter assigned the left-most Nike to Master A (perhaps Kallimachos) and the second to Master B (perhaps Paionios). He assigned the figures to the North side of the Parapet, in positions 10 and 11.
subject_description: Two Nikai leading a bull to sacrifice. The Nike on the left, who wears a belted chiton, restrains the bull by bracing her foot against a rock and tugging on a rope. The Nike on the right strides dramatically in 3/4-view to the right.
title: Two Nikai from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1011
summary: Nike running profile to the left
condition_description: Two rejoined fragments comprise most of the legs (but especially the drapery) of a Nike. The surface is severely chipped.
form_style_description: Carpenter placed this figure in position 43 on the South side of the Parapet.
title: Nike from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1014
summary: Nike wearing a belted chiton and a himation, and perhaps a sacrificial taenia (on her head), stands in 3/4-view to the left
collection_history: More of this figure is shown in an old drawing and a plaster cast, and the location of the lost fragments is unknown.
condition_description: Several rejoined fragments comprise the head, shoulders, torso, and portions of the wings of a Nike. The surface is worn on the face but in good condition on the body fragments.
form_style_description: Carpenter, who assigned this Nike to Master B (perhaps Paionios), placed it in position 13 on the North side of the Parapet.
title: Nike from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 995
summary: Nike moving to the right, wearing a himation (caught on a wing?)
condition_description: A single piece (?) comprises the right torso, right shoulder and upper thighs, as well as some drapery and wings, of a Nike. The surface is pitted, with some chips and stains.
form_style_description: Carpenter attributed to figure to Master C and assigned it to position 22 on the West side.
title: Nike from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 994
summary: Two Nikai erecting a trophy
findspot: Athens, Acropolis (some found by Bohn in 1880; others found later)
condition_description: This slab is reconstructed from many non-joining pieces, comprising the torso and right upper arm, right leg, left upper leg, and left hand, with trophy and helmet, of the left-most Nike, as well as the right elbow, right foreleg, and left foot, as well as drapery and wing fragments of the left-most Nike. (The head of the left-most Nike is visible in an old plaster cast.)
form_style_description: Carpenter attributed this slab to Master B (perhaps Paionios) and assigned these figures to positions 14 and 15 of the North side of the Parapet.
subject_description: One Nike, wearing a double belted chiton with cross straps, stands on tiptoe, placing a helmet on a trophy; her hair is arranged in a krobylos. The other Nike (to the right) puts her bare foot on a rock (?), and seems to stand next to a tree (or trophy?).
title: Two Nikai from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 7099
summary: Nike, wearing a belted chiton, advancing in 3/4-view to the left
condition_description: Two rejoined fragments comprise the upper torso and left upper arm, as well as some of the left thigh of a Nike. The surface is stained and chipped.
title: Nike from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 977
summary: Nike, wearing a billowy chiton with buttoned sleeves, and a himation around her waist, advancing in 3/4-view to the left, mounting a stair
condition_description: Almost all of this slab is preserved, although the right corners are chipped off. The wings--in such low relief that they are nearly inscribed--are well preserved, but much of the reliefs surface has been chipped off so that most of the Nike is lost--her head, details of her upper chest, both forearms, much of her right foreleg and the surface of her left leg.
form_style_description: Carpenter assigned this figure to a different sculptor than the Sandalbinder (<rs type="sculpture">Athens, Acropolis 973</rs>), but Brouskari suggests that they are stylistic akin to each other. This relief occupied the Easterbnist cirber if the Parapet, just to the West of the stair.
title: Nike from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Athens, Acropolis 1002
summary: Left wing of a Nike perhaps erecting a trophy
condition_description: Two rejoined fragments comprise most of the left wing of a Nike and associated drapery. The lower part of the surface is marred by solution cracks.
form_style_description: Carpenter attributed this figure to Master D and assigned it to position 30 on the West frieze of the Parapet.
title: Nike wing from the Nike Parapet Frieze

name: Istanbul 530
summary: Youthful male head with slanted eyes, Archaic smile, and shoulder-length hair
other_bibliography: See bibliography for <bibl>Samos F-S no. 47</bibl>, especially Eckstein.
condition_description: Broken off at the bottom of the neck; missing only the front of the nose (eroded off) and chin (chipped off), as well as most of the hair below the break. Otherwise the surface is in good condition.
material_description: White, coarse-grained marble with dark veins
subject_description: The beaded hair is indicated by horizontal and vertical striations on the scalp and down the back, but diagonal and vertical striations on the sides of the neck. The mass of hair falls down the back of the neck and is slightly rounded at the bottom. A thin row of vertical striations frames the hair over the crown.
title: Head of a colossal kouros

name: Samos F-S no. 59
summary: Toes of a left foot (of a kouros?), and the front of a rounded plinth to which they were attached
condition_description: The front of th eplinth has been broken off in a rough line just behind the toes of the left foot. The surface is slightly chipped and scratched, with some adhesions.
title: Fragment of a left foot

name: Samos F-S no. 60
summary: Standing female figure wearing a chiton and holding her skirt to her right side
condition_description: A: Three joining fragments comprising the left thigh. B: Single fragment of a lower hem. C: Single fragment of the right shoulder, showing details of the chiton sleeve. D: Single fragment of the left upper arm.
title: Fragmentary kore

name: Athens, NM 22
summary: Standing, draped figure of a female, perhaps Leto
findspot: Delos, near the Southwest corner of the Agora of the Italians (in 1884). Richter reports that it was found in the Temple of Artemis.
condition_description: A single piece comprises the bottom of neck, torso, shoulders, lower right arm, thighs, knees, and upper calves of a kore.
form_style_description: Karouzou suggests that this was the work of a Cycladic, perhaps Parian, sculptor.
subject_description: A female, who has been doubtfully identified as Leto, stands in a frontal pose, with her left leg slightly advanced. She wears a short Ionic himation with zigzag folds draped diagonally over her right shoulder, and perhaps veiled over her head, over a thin chiton. An epiblema, or short cape, falls from both shoulders down the back. Small holes on the chest indicate that she was decorated with metal attachments, probably more necklaces or locks of hair. Some sculpted locks fall over the chest, on either side. She holds her right arm at her side and clutches much of her skirt with her left hand.
technique_description:
Details such as the hair and the necklace are not carved in the back, which suggests that this statue may have been placed against a wall.

The right arm has been worked from a separate piece of marble and attached with a dowel.
title: Kore from Delos

name: Delian Group of Archaic Lions
summary: Nine or more seated lions (originally)
condition_description: Five large fragments and several small pieces are preserved.
material_description: Coarse-grained, white marble, probably from Naxos
form_style_description: The lions are aligned on a terrace that is oriented NNE to SSW. Each lion turns it head roughly to the east, in the direction of the lake.
subject_description: The lions are unusually slim, with narrow rear haunches and small heads.
title: Delian Group of Archaic Lions

name: Apollo of the Naxians
summary: Votive dedication of a kouros, probably a statue of Apollo, by the Naxians to Delos
documentary_references: Plutarch (in <bibl n="Plut. Vit. Nik. 3">Plut. Vit. Nik. 3</bibl>) mentioned that the great statue of the Naxians--without specifying what it represented--was knocked down by a palm tree that had been dedicated by Nikias in 417 B.C.
dimensions: H. restored 8.5-10.0 m. Torso: H. (neck to waist) 2.20 m; H. (waist to below buttocks) H. 1.20 m; circ. (waist) 2.76. Base (in situ): L. 3.47 m; W. 5.15 m; H. 0.70 m
collection: Delos Archaeological Museum, Temenos of Apollo at Delos, and London, British Mu
collection_history: Drawn by traveller S. de Vries in 1673 showing the entire head. It has been noted by modern travellers since ca. 1420 (when Bondelmonte saw the statue lying on the ground) and has been despoiled since then.
condition_description:
The torso is comprised of two pieces in situ at the Temenos of Apollo, part of the left hand (Delos A 4094), part of the left foot with some of the plinth (London B 322), and more of the inscribed base, also in situ at the Temenos of Apollo.

The surface of the fragments in situ are inscribed also with graffiti--the names of moderm travellers. The exposed surfaces are extremely weathered.
inscription: The inscribed statue base (in situ). On the east side (probably original) is inscribed: <foreign lang=Greek>[*T]*O *A*V*U*T*O *L*I*Q*O *E*M*I *A*N*D*R*I*A*S *K*A*I *T*O *S*F*E*L*A*S</foreign>, "I am of the same stone, statue and plinth." On the west side a later inscription (probably from the fourth century B.C., after the statue had fallen and was recreated) reads: <foreign lang=Greek>*N*A*C*I*O*I *A*P*O*L*L*W*N*I</foreign>, "[From] the Naxians to Apollo" (probably fourth century B.C.). The original dedication probably appeared on the missing portion of the base.
form_style_description: The form is simple, barely modeled, almost certainly a representative work of the Naxian school of sculptors.
subject_description: This belted (but otherwise nude) male figure seems to have had a large head, long neck, and sloping shoulders. Eight locks of hair seem to have fallen down the back where they terminated in a horizontal line comprised of spiral curls.
technique_description:
A hexagonal insertion mark in the upper surface of the plinth is visible.

Drill holes on the chest (four on the left and two on the right) indicate that locks of hair may have been made of metal (perhaps later additions).
title: Apollo of the Naxians

name: London B 322
summary: Four toes of the left foot are attached to a fragment of the plinth
dimensions: Plinth: H. 0.64 m; W. (front) 0.58 m. Toes: L. 0.35 m; W. 0.59 m
collection_history: This piece was presented to the British Museum in 1819 by Captain J. Murray of H.M. Sloop Satellite.
condition_description: The fragment is broken roughly on all sides and is severely weathered, as are the toes.
title: Parts of the left foot and plinth of the Apollo of the Naxians

name: Piraeus 4647
summary: Standing female figure wearing cross-bands over a peplos
findspot: Piraeus (found in 1959 in a cache together with the <rs type="sculpture">Piraeus Apollo</rs>, the <rs type="sculpture">Piraeus Athena</rs>, and a smaller statue of Artemis [<rs type="sculpture">Piraeus 4648</rs>]).
date_description: Dated by style to about the middle of the 4th century.
subject_description: This figure, probably of the goddess Artemis, wears a peplos with a long overfold, fastened with bands crossing her chest (as is customary for the huntress), as well as thick-soled sandals. Her hair is braided in a melon coiffure. She stands with her weight on her right leg, her left leg pulled back slightly, holds her left arm at her side. She raises her right hand ahead of her body, slightly above waist level, as if she is about to speak.
technique_description: Indirect, lost-wax method
title: Piraeus Large Artemis

name: Boston 10.70
summary: Bust of a female figure, perhaps Aphrodite
condition_description: The piece is broken off below the neck; much of the back of the head is missing; the face is scratched and pitted, while the end of the nose is broken off.
title: Female bust from Chios

name: Boston 52.1741
summary: Idealized male face, wearing a lion's-head scalp
condition_description: Only the front of the head, i.e. the face, the front of the helmet, and some intervening hair, have been preserved. The front left of the lion's maul is missing. The surface is slightly pockmarked on the left and marred with dark gray adhesions on the right.
subject_description: The identification as Herakles is assured because of the (Nemean) lion's-scalp helmet, which was Herakles' life-long attribute after he defeated the Nemean lion. The likeness of the face to that of the idealized Alexander the Great, sculpted by Lysippos, has encouraged scholars to interpret this piece as a portrait of Alexander in the guise of Herakles.
technique_description: Given the state of this piece it is unclear whether this head was originally sculpted in high relief or in the round.
title: Herakles from Sparta

name: Boston 04.12
summary: Bearded male head, with long, wavy hair parted in the center
condition_description: The nose is chipped at the front, but the surface is otherwise in excellent condition.
title: Head of Zeus from Mylasa

name: Athens, NM 4545
summary: Left calf of a male leg
collection_history: Tranferred to Athens from the Megara Museum in 1965.
condition_description: This fragment is broken roughly at the top and the bottom--just below the knee and above the ankle; the surface is pitted and scratched, but the contours are well preserved.
title: Left calf of the kouros from Megara

name: East Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros
summary: Iliupersis
title: East Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros
in_group: Sculptures from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: West Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros
summary: Amazonomachy
title: West Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros
in_group: Sculptures from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Akroteria from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros
summary: Windblown figures
title: Akroteria from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Metopes from Mycenae
summary: Battle scenes, perhaps the Iliupersis
form_style_description: Although the metopes are traditionally taken to come from the Archaic Temple of Athena (Boardman suggests that they decorated a dado frieze rather than a metope frieze) it has also been suggested that they decorated a nearby altar: see A.J.B. Wace, <hi rend="ital">JHS</hi> 59 (1939) 40. The work has been thought to be by a Corinthian sculptor.
title: Metopes from Mycenae

name: Athens, NM 157
summary: Female figure, perhaps Aura (personified breeze) on the back of a horse
condition_description: Some fragments have been rejoined. The female figure is missing her left forearm and her feet, as well as some chips of drapery. Much of the horse has been broken off: the head and top of the neck, the forelegs, and the tail.
form_style_description: Transparent drapery typical of early fourth century B.C.
subject_description: This woman, previously identified as a Nereid but now taken by most scholars to represent an Aura, or breeze, is seated comfortably on the back of a horse, who rises from the ocean waves. She turns her upper body in 3/4-view to the left. She gazes down slightly, raises her (now missing) left forearm, and puts her right arm around the back of the horse's neck. She wears a belted windblown chiton with medium-length sleeves. Some of the voluminous skirt is piled in her lap. For Stewart's distinction of this Aura as the South (land) breeze, see the discussion of <rs type="sculpture">Athens, NM 156</rs>.
technique_description: A dowel hole on the neck indicates where the horse's metal harness would have been added.
title: (West?) corner akroterion from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros
in_whole: Akroteria from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Athens, NM 136
summary: An Amazon, perhaps Penthesilea, riding 3/4-view to the right
condition_description: The Amazon lacks both arms, below the shoulders, head, and feet; the horse lacks head and top of neck, left forelegs, right front hoof, tail, and lower hindlegs. The surface is slightly stained and weathered.
form_style_description: Because of the height of this figure, scholars have determined that it was probably placed at the center of the pediment.
subject_description: An Amazon rider, perhaps the Queen Penthesilea, wearing a chlamys, or cape, fluttering at her back, a belted chitoniskos, and high leather boots (embades) rides a horse in 3/4-view to the right. While the horse rears on its hind legs, the Amazon raises her right arm, perhasp to thrust a spear at the enemy.
technique_description: Some dowel holes on the neck of the horse indicate where the bridal would have been attached, probably worked in metal.
title: Central West Pediment figure from Epidauros
in_whole: West Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Athens, NM 137 and 142
summary: Wounded Amazon
condition_description: This piece is reconstructed from several fragments, and the head has been rejoined with plaster at the break. The  forearms and legs below the thighs are missing.
subject_description: The figure of a wounded Amazon arcs toward the ground, probably as she falls off of her horse. The spear of the warrior who killed her was probably lodged in her right breast, where there is a hole. She wears the traditional Amazon garb of a belted chitoniskos that is worn over the left shoulder. Her head, with partially closed eyes, and left arm fell to the ground, while her left arm lay at her side.
title: Pedimental figure from Epidauros
in_whole: West Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Athens, NM 4492
summary: Dead body of a nude youth
condition_description: Most of the head is missing, as is the right arm, below the shoulder, and parts of the legs. What remains has been reconstructed from several fragments.
form_style_description: This figure is generally accepted as the left corner figure of the West Pediment.
subject_description: The nude body of a dead (Greek) youth is streatched on the ground, toward the left, with his legs extended and crossed. He lies on a large garment, probably his chlamys, or cape. His head was tilted back, and his left arm thrown behind his head.
title: Pedimental figure from Epidauros
in_whole: West Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Athens, NM 146
summary: Female figure, perhaps Hecuba, resting on her knees
condition_description: The upper body is missing.
subject_description: A woman kneels to the left, on her knees; her himation falls heavily on the figure of another person who is being pulled back from her.
title: Pedimental figure from Epidauros
in_whole: East Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Athens, NM 146a
summary: Trojan woman attacking a Greek warrior
condition_description: Only the right part of the female figure is preserved, attached to the right leg of the warrior.
subject_description: A kneeling woman raises a weapon, possibly an axe, above the body of a warrior who moves to the right (his right leg remains).
title: Pedimental figure from Epidauros
in_whole: East Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Athens, NM 144
summary: Head of Priam being pulled by the hand of a Greek
condition_description: The lower part of the head has broken off, while the top is well preserved, broken off at the middle of the hand. The surface is slightly pitted.
subject_description: This fragment preserves the head of a bearded mature man, probably King Priam, wearing on his head a Persian mitra, which has been grabbed by the hand of a Greek. The eyes evoke extreme pathos, being deep set and tilted up towards the nose; the pathetic expression is accentuated by the furrowed brow.
title: Pedimental figure from Epidauros
in_whole: East Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Athens, NM 163
summary: Frontal head of a lion, with his tongue protruding
title: Lion's head spout from a gutter
in_whole: Sculptures from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Athens, NM 4642
summary: A woman bending to protect a small kneeling girl
condition_description: The weathering is greatest on the front of the group.
form_style_description: This group was probably placed left of center in the East Pediment.
technique_description: These two figures were carved from a single block of marble.
title: Pedimental figures from Epidauros
in_whole: East Pediment from the Temple of Asklepios at Epidauros

name: Athens, NM 173
summary: Asklepios seated on a throne
condition_description: Right arm and feet missing, as well as upper left part of panel.
form_style_description: This relief and <rs type="sculpture">Athens, NM 174</rs> were earlier taken to be architectural sculptures, perhaps metopes or <hi rend="ital">typoi</hi> (recorded in the buildings inscriptions), but it is more likely that they are votive reliefs. The absence of frames makes it difficult for the original placement to be understood. Karouzou suggests that this work may have been done by one of the leading sculptors of the pedimental figures on the <rs type="building">Epidauros, Temple of Asklepios</rs>.
subject_description: A majestic, bearded, mature male figure, almost certainly Asklepios, is seated 3/4-view to the right on a cushioned throne, with is feet on a footstool. He wears his himation around his lower body and legs, and it is draped up over the back of his chair, on which he also rests he (now missing) right arm. He holds his left palm open, above his lap, perhaps in a sign of benediction. He crosses his sandalled feet.
title: Relief showing seated Asklepios

name: Thasos Zeus and Hera Gate
summary: Iris standing before a seated Hera
other_bibliography: Y. Garlan, <hi rend="ital">BCH</hi> 1966, 586-95; P. Bernard, <hi rend="ital">BCH</hi> 1965, 64-89; <hi rend="ital">BCH</hi> 1964, 866
dimensions: H. (of the block on which the relief is placed): 3.94 m
condition_description: Much of the higher relief has splintered off: the eagle, Hera's left arm, and Iris' right shoulder.
other_notes: A figure of Zeus, seated similarly on a throne, shown facing the city, and accompanied by Hermes, decorated the left of this entrance.
form_style_description: This relief decorates a sunken rectangular panel on the tall rectangular block that rises from the right side of the threshold to the gate. Hera is therefore shown seated toward the city, and would be visible to the right as one entered the gate.
subject_description: Within a pedimental niche, with an eagle akroterion, is Hera, seated profile to the left, on a large throne; she rests her feet (with her right foot slightly advanced) on a footstool. She wears an epiblema, or shawl, over a chiton, and holds a scepter in her upraied left hand, while she holds a portion of her veil (in an <hi rend="ital">anakalypsis</hi> gesture), with her right hand. In front of her (in the left of the relief) stands Iris, her messenger, in a near frontal pose, with her head turned profile to the right, towards Hera. One of her wings rises in the space between her body and that of Hera.
title: Relief on the Gate of Zeus and Hera
assoc_building: Thasos, Gate of Zeus and Hera

name: Thasos 652
summary: A female figure, the personification of Comedy, wearing a high belted chiton and a himation draped around her crossed legs
condition_description: The head (separately worked, and socketed in) is missing, as are the right arm, below the shoulder, the left hand, and the right foot. The surface is stained, and patches are covered with dark adhesions.
inscription: The statue is identified by the inscription on the base of the exedra: "Comedy. Philemon was an actor."
subject_description: This figure probably held a comic mask in her upraised left hand.
title: Statue of Comedy
in_group: Thasos, Large Exedra in the Dionysion

name: Thasos, Large Exedra in the Dionysion
summary: Dionysiac thiasos
inscription: The group is dated on the basis of the style of the relevant inscription: See G. Daux, <hi rend="ital">BCH</hi> 1926, 234 ff.
subject_description: Dionysos (center), Tragedy (?), Comedy, Dithyramb, Nykterinos, and other members of the Dionysiac circle, on a rounded raised podium, sheltered by three walls and preceded by a porch.
title: Large Exedra in the Sanctuary of Dionysos at Thasos

name: Thasos 17
summary: The face of an old blind person on a mask held by the personification of Tragedy
title: Tragic Mask
in_whole: Thasos, Large Exedra in the Dionysion

name: Thasos Theater Reliefs
summary: Two or more reliefs, of similar dimensions, found in the theater at Thasos
title: Thasos Theater Reliefs

name: Left thigh of Samian Colossal Kouros
summary: Inscribed left thigh and knee
other_bibliography: H. Kyrieleis and H. Kienast, <hi rend="ital">AA</hi> 1985, 366, 392, 442, figs. 1, 11, 13
findspot: Samos, Sanctuary of Hera, in the wall of a Hellenistic building, near the North side of the Sacred Way (in 1973)
condition_description: This fragment comprises the leg from the top of the thigh to just below the knee. The upper edge is rounded, suggesting that the fragment was exposed to weather for a while.
inscription: The dedicatory inscription, "Ischys son of Rhesos dediated it," runs in three lines along the thigh, from the knee to the thigh: <Foreign lang=Greek>*I*S*X*Y*S<lb>*A*N*E*Q*H*K*E*N<lb>*O*R*H*S*I*O*S</foreign>
